assessment.title: DS2 Cognitive Architecture Assessment
assessment.description: Behavioral marker assessment for Analytical Mechanics Intelligence (AMI) and Conceptual Morphogenesis Intelligence (CMI)

questions.text: Can you detect subtle symbolic inconsistencies in formal derivations?
questions.context: For example: spotting when a sign error propagates through equations, or when tensor indices are mismatched.

options.text: Yes - I routinely catch subtle symbolic errors others miss
Usually - I catch most inconsistencies with careful review
Sometimes - I catch obvious errors but miss subtle ones
Rarely - I often overlook symbolic inconsistencies

questions.text: When reviewing mathematical proofs, how often do you notice notation errors before they affect the conclusion?
questions.context: Such as inconsistent use of subscripts, forgotten negative signs, or misapplied operators.

options.text: Almost always - notation errors jump out at me immediately
Frequently - I catch most notation issues during review
Occasionally - I catch them if I'm specifically looking
Seldom - notation errors often slip past me

questions.text: In code or formal specifications, do you naturally verify that variable types and units remain consistent throughout?
questions.context: Checking that meters aren't added to seconds, or that function return types match their declarations.

options.text: Yes - type/unit consistency is something I automatically track
Usually - I verify consistency for important variables
Sometimes - I check when something seems off
Rarely - I rely on compilers or tools to catch these

questions.text: When following a chain of logical substitutions, can you tell when an intermediate step violates the rules?
questions.context: Like substituting before distributing, or applying an operation that isn't valid for the domain.

options.text: Yes - invalid substitutions feel wrong even before I identify why
Usually - I catch invalid steps if I trace carefully
Sometimes - I catch obvious violations only
Rarely - I accept intermediate steps if the conclusion seems right

questions.text: How reliably do you catch when someone uses the same symbol to mean different things in the same argument?
questions.context: For example, 'n' meaning sample size in one place and an arbitrary integer elsewhere.

options.text: Very reliably - symbol overloading immediately triggers suspicion
Fairly reliably - I notice if the context shifts noticeably
Somewhat - I catch it if the meanings conflict obviously
Not reliably - I tend to assume symbols mean the same thing

questions.text: Can you manipulate multi-variable systems simultaneously in your head?
questions.context: For example: tracking how changing three parameters affects a system's behavior without writing it down.

options.text: Yes - I can hold and manipulate 4+ variables mentally
Usually - I can manage 3 variables reliably
Sometimes - 2 variables is my comfortable limit
Rarely - I need to write things down to track relationships

questions.text: When debugging, can you mentally trace how multiple interacting state variables change through execution?
questions.context: Tracking how loop counters, accumulated values, and flags evolve together.

options.text: Yes - I can simulate multiple state variables mentally through many steps
Usually - I can track 3 interacting variables for moderate sequences
Sometimes - I need to add print statements for more than 2 variables
Rarely - I rely heavily on debuggers or logging

questions.text: Can you predict how a system responds to simultaneous changes in multiple inputs?
questions.context: Like understanding what happens when you increase price, decrease marketing, and change seasonality at once.

options.text: Yes - I can intuit combined effects of 4+ simultaneous changes
Usually - I can reason about 3 simultaneous changes accurately
Sometimes - I can handle 2 changes but more requires analysis
Rarely - I prefer to change one variable at a time

questions.text: In strategic planning, can you mentally model how multiple constraints interact?
questions.context: Budget, timeline, scope, and resource constraints all affecting each other.

options.text: Yes - I naturally see how adjusting one constraint ripples through others
Usually - I can track the main interactions with effort
Sometimes - I need to map it out to see interactions clearly
Rarely - I tend to consider constraints one at a time

questions.text: When solving optimization problems, can you mentally track trade-offs across multiple dimensions?
questions.context: Understanding how improving one metric affects several others simultaneously.

options.text: Yes - I intuitively sense multi-dimensional trade-off surfaces
Usually - I can track 3-way trade-offs reliably
Sometimes - I focus on the primary trade-off and check others separately
Rarely - I optimize dimensions sequentially rather than jointly

questions.text: Do you produce derivations from first principles when prompted?
questions.context: Rather than recalling formulas, you reconstruct them from foundational axioms.

options.text: Yes - I prefer deriving over memorizing; I can rebuild most formulas
Usually - I derive when needed but also memorize common results
Sometimes - I can derive simple things but rely on memory for complex ones
Rarely - I primarily rely on memorized formulas and procedures

questions.text: When you encounter an unfamiliar problem, do you start by identifying the fundamental principles that govern it?
questions.context: Breaking down to basic physics, economics, or logic before building up a solution.

options.text: Yes - I always seek the underlying principles first
Usually - I look for principles when pattern-matching fails
Sometimes - I try analogies first, then principles if stuck
Rarely - I look for similar solved problems to adapt

questions.text: Can you explain why standard procedures work by deriving them from basics?
questions.context: Not just knowing how to use a technique, but understanding why it's valid.

options.text: Yes - I can derive most standard techniques from axioms
Usually - I understand the derivation for common techniques
Sometimes - I know derivations for some basics only
Rarely - I apply techniques without needing to know why they work

questions.text: When given a black-box solution, do you feel compelled to understand its mechanism?
questions.context: Not satisfied with 'it works' - wanting to know the underlying logic.

options.text: Yes - I need to understand the mechanism to trust the solution
Usually - I investigate mechanisms for important solutions
Sometimes - I accept black boxes if they're well-tested
Rarely - results matter more to me than mechanisms

questions.text: Do you question assumptions that others take for granted?
questions.context: Asking 'why is this true?' about things everyone else accepts as given.

options.text: Yes - I regularly uncover hidden assumptions others miss
Usually - I question assumptions when something seems off
Sometimes - I question obvious assumptions only
Rarely - I tend to accept standard assumptions

questions.text: Do you consistently check units, boundary conditions, or limiting cases?
questions.context: For example: verifying that an equation gives sensible results when variables approach 0, infinity, or known limits.

options.text: Yes - it's automatic; I always verify dimensional consistency and limits
Usually - I check when the problem seems important
Sometimes - I check when something seems wrong
Rarely - I trust the derivation if the algebra seems correct

questions.text: When writing code, do you instinctively consider edge cases like empty inputs, nulls, or overflow?
questions.context: Testing what happens at the boundaries of valid input ranges.

options.text: Yes - edge cases are the first thing I think about
Usually - I check major edge cases systematically
Sometimes - I catch edge cases when tests fail
Rarely - I focus on the happy path first

questions.text: Do you verify that your solutions behave correctly at extreme values?
questions.context: Checking what happens as parameters get very large, very small, or approach special values.

options.text: Yes - I always test extremes as a sanity check
Usually - I check extremes for critical calculations
Sometimes - I check if the problem hints at edge issues
Rarely - I assume solutions generalize smoothly

questions.text: When designing systems, do you explicitly define what happens at operational limits?
questions.context: Specifying behavior when capacity is reached, resources are exhausted, or timeouts occur.

options.text: Yes - boundary behavior is a core part of my designs
Usually - I define limits for key failure modes
Sometimes - I address limits when they become apparent
Rarely - I design for normal operation primarily

questions.text: Do you test whether your conclusions still hold when key assumptions are relaxed?
questions.context: Checking robustness by seeing how sensitive results are to assumption violations.

options.text: Yes - sensitivity analysis is standard practice for me
Usually - I check sensitivity for important decisions
Sometimes - I check if I'm unsure about assumptions
Rarely - I accept conclusions if assumptions seem reasonable

questions.text: Can you construct formal proofs with rigorous logical structure?
questions.context: Building arguments where each step follows necessarily from previous steps with explicit justification.

options.text: Yes - I can construct and verify multi-step formal proofs
Usually - I can build proofs but may miss some rigor
Sometimes - I can follow proofs but struggle to construct them
Rarely - formal proof construction is not my strength

questions.text: Can you structure an argument so that each claim is explicitly justified?
questions.context: Making the logical dependencies between statements clear and traceable.

options.text: Yes - I naturally build arguments with explicit justification chains
Usually - I can structure arguments formally when needed
Sometimes - I make arguments but may skip justification steps
Rarely - I argue more intuitively than formally

questions.text: When you need to prove something, can you identify the appropriate proof technique?
questions.context: Choosing between direct proof, contradiction, induction, construction, etc.

options.text: Yes - I select proof strategies based on problem structure
Usually - I know several techniques and can often match them
Sometimes - I try techniques until one works
Rarely - I'm not fluent in formal proof techniques

questions.text: Can you spot gaps in someone else's proof or argument?
questions.context: Identifying where logical steps are missing, unjustified, or invalid.

options.text: Yes - I catch logical gaps that others accept
Usually - I find gaps with careful analysis
Sometimes - I spot obvious gaps only
Rarely - I tend to trust structured-looking arguments

questions.text: Do you distinguish between 'plausible' and 'proven' in your reasoning?
questions.context: Knowing when you have intuition versus certainty, evidence versus proof.

options.text: Yes - I'm precise about my confidence levels and their basis
Usually - I distinguish proven from likely for important claims
Sometimes - I blur the distinction when evidence is strong
Rarely - I treat high confidence as equivalent to certainty

questions.text: Can you decompose complex procedures into precise algorithmic steps?
questions.context: Breaking down a process so that each step is unambiguous and mechanically executable.

options.text: Yes - I naturally think in algorithms and can specify exact procedures
Usually - I can create clear procedures with some effort
Sometimes - my procedures work but may have ambiguous steps
Rarely - I think more holistically than algorithmically

questions.text: Can you write instructions that someone could follow mechanically without interpretation?
questions.context: Creating procedures where no judgment calls are needed - every decision is specified.

options.text: Yes - I can write fully unambiguous executable specifications
Usually - my instructions need minimal interpretation
Sometimes - my instructions require some contextual judgment
Rarely - my instructions assume shared understanding

questions.text: When facing a complex task, do you naturally break it into ordered sub-tasks?
questions.context: Creating a clear sequence where later steps depend on earlier results.

options.text: Yes - I immediately see the task as a dependency graph
Usually - I decompose tasks when they're non-trivial
Sometimes - I decompose only when I get stuck
Rarely - I prefer to tackle things holistically

questions.text: Can you identify which parts of a process can run in parallel versus which must be sequential?
questions.context: Understanding dependencies well enough to know what can happen simultaneously.

options.text: Yes - I naturally see parallelization opportunities
Usually - I can identify obvious parallelism
Sometimes - I find parallelism with explicit analysis
Rarely - I default to sequential thinking

questions.text: Do you specify termination conditions explicitly when defining iterative processes?
questions.context: Clearly stating when a loop, search, or refinement should stop.

options.text: Yes - I always define explicit stopping criteria
Usually - I specify termination for important iterations
Sometimes - I rely on intuitive 'good enough' stopping
Rarely - I stop processes when results seem satisfactory

questions.text: Can you trace how errors propagate through a system of calculations?
questions.context: Understanding how uncertainty or mistakes in inputs affect outputs through chains of operations.

options.text: Yes - I can mentally track error propagation through complex chains
Usually - I can trace errors through moderate complexity
Sometimes - I can trace simple error chains
Rarely - I find error propagation analysis difficult

questions.text: When you see an incorrect output, can you trace backward to identify which input caused it?
questions.context: Root cause analysis through chains of transformations.

options.text: Yes - I can efficiently trace errors back through complex systems
Usually - I can trace back through moderate chains
Sometimes - I trace back through obvious paths only
Rarely - I find root cause analysis challenging

questions.text: Can you predict how uncertainty in measurements will affect your final conclusions?
questions.context: Understanding how input precision limits output confidence.

options.text: Yes - I track uncertainty propagation as a matter of course
Usually - I consider uncertainty for critical calculations
Sometimes - I think about uncertainty when explicitly required
Rarely - I work with point estimates mainly

questions.text: Do you understand how rounding or approximation errors accumulate?
questions.context: Knowing when small errors compound into significant ones through repeated operations.

options.text: Yes - I'm always aware of error accumulation risks
Usually - I check for accumulation in iterative processes
Sometimes - I notice when accumulation causes visible problems
Rarely - I assume small errors stay small

questions.text: Can you identify which inputs a result is most sensitive to?
questions.context: Knowing where small changes in inputs cause large changes in outputs.

options.text: Yes - I intuitively sense sensitivity structure
Usually - I can identify high-sensitivity inputs with analysis
Sometimes - I find dominant sensitivities only
Rarely - I treat all inputs as equally impactful

questions.text: Do you exploit symmetries to simplify problems?
questions.context: Recognizing when a problem has symmetry that reduces its effective dimensionality or complexity.

options.text: Yes - I actively seek and exploit symmetries as a primary strategy
Usually - I recognize obvious symmetries
Sometimes - I notice symmetries when pointed out
Rarely - I tend to solve problems without considering symmetry

questions.text: When facing a complex problem, do you look for invariants that must be preserved?
questions.context: Quantities or relationships that don't change under the operations you're considering.

options.text: Yes - finding invariants is one of my first moves
Usually - I look for invariants when problems seem hard
Sometimes - I use invariants when they're suggested
Rarely - I don't typically think in terms of invariants

questions.text: Do you recognize when a problem has rotational, translational, or other structural symmetry?
questions.context: Seeing that the problem looks the same from different vantage points or under transformations.

options.text: Yes - I immediately perceive structural symmetries
Usually - I notice symmetries when I'm looking for simplifications
Sometimes - I see obvious geometric symmetries
Rarely - I don't naturally perceive abstract symmetries

questions.text: Can you reduce a problem's complexity by choosing the right coordinate system or reference frame?
questions.context: Selecting representations where symmetries become apparent and exploitable.

options.text: Yes - choosing good coordinates is a key part of my approach
Usually - I consider alternative representations for hard problems
Sometimes - I try different coordinates when stuck
Rarely - I work in whatever coordinates are given

questions.text: Do you use symmetry arguments to rule out possibilities without calculating?
questions.context: Knowing that certain outcomes are impossible because they would violate symmetry.

options.text: Yes - symmetry arguments often let me skip calculations
Usually - I use symmetry to constrain solutions
Sometimes - I verify symmetry constraints after calculating
Rarely - I calculate rather than argue from symmetry

questions.text: Can you detect logical contradictions in complex arguments?
questions.context: Identifying when conclusions don't follow from premises, or when hidden assumptions create inconsistency.

options.text: Yes - I quickly spot logical flaws even in sophisticated arguments
Usually - I catch contradictions with careful analysis
Sometimes - I catch obvious contradictions
Rarely - logical analysis is not my primary mode

questions.text: When someone presents a chain of reasoning, do you verify each inference independently?
questions.context: Checking that each step actually follows, not just that the conclusion sounds reasonable.

options.text: Yes - I validate each logical step individually
Usually - I check key inferences in important arguments
Sometimes - I check if the overall conclusion seems off
Rarely - I evaluate arguments holistically

questions.text: Can you identify when an argument assumes what it's trying to prove?
questions.context: Spotting circular reasoning or question-begging in disguised forms.

options.text: Yes - I catch circular reasoning even when it's well-hidden
Usually - I notice circularity when I trace assumptions
Sometimes - I catch obvious circularity
Rarely - circular arguments often seem valid to me initially

questions.text: Do you notice when the same term is used with different meanings within an argument?
questions.context: Equivocation - where a word shifts meaning to make an invalid inference seem valid.

options.text: Yes - I'm sensitive to semantic shifts in arguments
Usually - I catch equivocation in careful reading
Sometimes - I notice when meanings are obviously different
Rarely - I tend to assume consistent meaning

questions.text: Can you tell when a conclusion is stronger than the evidence supports?
questions.context: Recognizing overgeneralization, unwarranted certainty, or unjustified scope.

options.text: Yes - I'm attuned to the gap between evidence and claims
Usually - I notice when conclusions are too strong
Sometimes - I question very bold claims
Rarely - strong conclusions from evidence seem natural

questions.text: Can you make accurate order-of-magnitude estimates for unfamiliar quantities?
questions.context: Fermi estimation - quickly approximating values through chains of reasoning.

options.text: Yes - I can reliably estimate within an order of magnitude
Usually - my estimates are often reasonably close
Sometimes - I can estimate familiar domains only
Rarely - quantitative estimation is difficult for me

questions.text: Can you quickly sanity-check whether a number 'makes sense'?
questions.context: Knowing that 'million' is wrong when it should be 'billion', or recognizing implausible rates.

options.text: Yes - wrong magnitudes immediately trigger suspicion
Usually - I catch clearly wrong magnitudes
Sometimes - I catch errors in domains I know well
Rarely - I accept numbers without magnitude checking

questions.text: Can you decompose an unknown quantity into estimable components?
questions.context: Breaking 'how many X in Y' into a chain of smaller estimates you can make.

options.text: Yes - I naturally decompose unknowns into estimable pieces
Usually - I can find decompositions with some thought
Sometimes - I decompose simple quantities only
Rarely - I don't know how to approach unknown quantities

questions.text: Do you have reliable intuitions for common quantities like populations, distances, or rates?
questions.context: A mental library of reference values you can anchor estimates to.

options.text: Yes - I have a rich set of reference quantities across domains
Usually - I know key reference values in my areas
Sometimes - I know a few common reference points
Rarely - I don't maintain mental reference values

questions.text: Can you estimate how long a task will take before starting it?
questions.context: Time estimation based on decomposition and experience with similar work.

options.text: Yes - my time estimates are usually accurate
Usually - I estimate time reasonably for familiar tasks
Sometimes - my estimates are often off by 2x or more
Rarely - time estimation is very difficult for me

questions.text: Can you generate new ontologies for a problem from scratch?
questions.context: Creating entirely new categories, distinctions, or conceptual frameworks to understand a domain.

options.text: Yes - I regularly create novel conceptual frameworks
Usually - I can create new frameworks when existing ones fail
Sometimes - I adapt existing frameworks more than create new ones
Rarely - I prefer working within established frameworks

questions.text: Do you invent new categories when existing ones don't carve reality well?
questions.context: Recognizing that standard classifications miss important distinctions.

options.text: Yes - I routinely create better categories than what exists
Usually - I modify categories when they clearly fail
Sometimes - I work with given categories mostly
Rarely - I accept standard categorizations

questions.text: Can you define new concepts that didn't exist before but should?
questions.context: Coining terms for phenomena everyone experiences but no one has named.

options.text: Yes - I often identify and name previously unnamed things
Usually - I can articulate new concepts when needed
Sometimes - I use existing terms even when they don't quite fit
Rarely - I work within existing vocabulary

questions.text: When you encounter a messy problem, do you restructure how it's conceptualized?
questions.context: Redefining what the entities and relationships are, not just how to handle given ones.

options.text: Yes - reconceptualization is often my first move
Usually - I restructure when the given framing seems wrong
Sometimes - I try to work within given structures first
Rarely - I accept problem structures as given

questions.text: Do you see multiple valid ways to slice the same domain into categories?
questions.context: Understanding that taxonomies are choices, not discoveries.

options.text: Yes - I see categorization as a design choice with trade-offs
Usually - I recognize that different categorizations serve different purposes
Sometimes - I see alternatives when prompted
Rarely - I see categories as natural or given

questions.text: Can you reframe a problem in a completely different reference frame?
questions.context: Seeing a problem from an entirely different perspective that transforms what the problem even is.

options.text: Yes - I naturally see problems from multiple, radically different frames
Usually - I can shift frames with deliberate effort
Sometimes - I can shift to related frames but not radically different ones
Rarely - I tend to stay within my initial framing

questions.text: Can you see a situation from a stakeholder perspective very different from your own?
questions.context: Understanding how a problem looks entirely different to someone with different goals or values.

options.text: Yes - I can genuinely adopt alien perspectives, not just simulate them
Usually - I can see through others' eyes with effort
Sometimes - I can imagine obvious differences in perspective
Rarely - I tend to project my own perspective onto others

questions.text: Do you spontaneously see how a problem would look from a different discipline's viewpoint?
questions.context: A physicist seeing economics problems, or an artist seeing engineering problems.

options.text: Yes - I automatically translate problems into multiple disciplinary frames
Usually - I can reframe into disciplines I know something about
Sometimes - I see cross-disciplinary connections when they're obvious
Rarely - I stay within my home discipline's framing

questions.text: Can you view a familiar situation as if encountering it for the first time?
questions.context: Defamiliarization - stripping away assumptions to see things fresh.

options.text: Yes - I can deliberately induce beginner's mind
Usually - I can question familiar framings when prompted
Sometimes - I notice when familiarity might blind me
Rarely - I rely on established understanding

questions.text: When an approach isn't working, do you question whether you're solving the right problem?
questions.context: Stepping back to reconsider the problem definition, not just the solution method.

options.text: Yes - I regularly question the problem itself, not just my solutions
Usually - I reconsider problem framing when stuck
Sometimes - I try many solutions before questioning the problem
Rarely - I assume the problem is given correctly

questions.text: Do you tolerate paradox and produce new insights from contradictions?
questions.context: Holding contradictory ideas simultaneously and using the tension to generate understanding.

options.text: Yes - paradoxes are generative; I find them productive
Usually - I can sit with contradiction long enough to learn from it
Sometimes - I tolerate paradox but seek resolution quickly
Rarely - contradictions feel uncomfortable; I resolve them immediately

questions.text: Can you hold two contradictory beliefs simultaneously to explore their tension?
questions.context: Not resolving contradiction prematurely, but using it as a thinking tool.

options.text: Yes - I can maintain productive cognitive dissonance indefinitely
Usually - I can hold contradictions for useful periods
Sometimes - I can tolerate contradiction briefly
Rarely - contradictions create pressure I need to resolve

questions.text: Do you find apparent contradictions interesting rather than disturbing?
questions.context: Seeing paradox as a signal that something interesting is happening, not as a problem to fix.

options.text: Yes - contradictions excite me; they often point to deeper truth
Usually - I find some contradictions intellectually stimulating
Sometimes - I can appreciate contradiction in certain contexts
Rarely - contradictions mainly signal errors to correct

questions.text: Can you entertain an idea seriously even if you believe it's false?
questions.context: Steelmanning - understanding the strongest version of views you disagree with.

options.text: Yes - I can fully inhabit perspectives I ultimately reject
Usually - I can explore opposing views seriously
Sometimes - I try to understand views I disagree with
Rarely - I focus on views I think are correct

questions.text: When you discover your beliefs contradict each other, is your first impulse curiosity or discomfort?
questions.context: Your emotional response to finding inconsistency in your own thinking.

options.text: Curiosity - internal contradictions are opportunities to learn
Mostly curiosity - I investigate after initial surprise
Mixed - some discomfort but I can work through it
Discomfort - I need to resolve contradictions quickly

questions.text: Can you compress a multi-domain concept into a single, manipulable mental object?
questions.context: Taking complex ideas from different fields and chunking them into unified conceptual handles.

options.text: Yes - I create unified abstractions that span domains
Usually - I can compress within domains
Sometimes - I keep domain concepts separate
Rarely - I work with ideas in their original form

questions.text: Can you summarize a complex system in a single sentence that captures its essence?
questions.context: Distilling to the core insight without losing what matters.

options.text: Yes - I can compress complex systems to their essential logic
Usually - I can capture main ideas concisely
Sometimes - my summaries require several sentences
Rarely - I need to explain details to convey understanding

questions.text: Do you create mental 'handles' that let you manipulate complex ideas as single units?
questions.context: Chunking - packaging complexity so you can think with it rather than about it.

options.text: Yes - I create powerful conceptual handles naturally
Usually - I chunk familiar complexities
Sometimes - I use existing terms as handles
Rarely - I think through components rather than chunks

questions.text: Can you explain a technical concept to a novice in a way that gives them real understanding?
questions.context: Not dumbing down but finding the compressed representation that conveys the core.

options.text: Yes - I can transmit understanding without technical details
Usually - I can simplify most concepts effectively
Sometimes - I simplify but lose important nuance
Rarely - technical concepts require technical explanations

questions.text: When you learn something new, do you quickly integrate it with what you already know?
questions.context: New information immediately connects and compresses with existing knowledge.

options.text: Yes - new learning immediately restructures my existing understanding
Usually - I connect new ideas to existing frameworks
Sometimes - I store new knowledge somewhat separately at first
Rarely - I keep new information in its own compartment

questions.text: Can you transfer structural insights between seemingly unrelated domains?
questions.context: Seeing that the deep structure of one problem is isomorphic to another from a different field.

options.text: Yes - I constantly see structural parallels across domains
Usually - I make cross-domain connections when prompted
Sometimes - I see connections between related domains
Rarely - I keep domain knowledge compartmentalized

questions.text: Do solutions from one field spontaneously suggest themselves when you're working in another?
questions.context: Cross-pollination happening automatically without deliberate search.

options.text: Yes - ideas from other domains constantly intrude productively
Usually - I often see relevant parallels from other areas
Sometimes - I notice connections between obviously related fields
Rarely - I focus on domain-native solutions

questions.text: Can you recognize when two problems have the same underlying structure despite surface differences?
questions.context: Seeing isomorphism - that different-looking problems are mathematically or logically identical.

options.text: Yes - I see through surface features to structural identity
Usually - I recognize shared structure in similar domains
Sometimes - I notice obvious structural similarities
Rarely - surface features dominate my perception

questions.text: Do you use metaphors from one domain to generate insights in another?
questions.context: Not just communicating with metaphor but thinking with it - letting it guide discovery.

options.text: Yes - metaphorical thinking drives many of my insights
Usually - metaphors help me understand new domains
Sometimes - I use metaphors for communication mainly
Rarely - I prefer literal domain-specific thinking

questions.text: When you master something in one area, does it improve your ability in seemingly unrelated areas?
questions.context: Transfer learning - skills and insights generalizing beyond their original context.

options.text: Yes - deep learning transfers broadly for me
Usually - I see transfer to related areas
Sometimes - I notice limited transfer effects
Rarely - skills stay specific to where I learned them

questions.text: Can you recognize emergent properties that aren't present in components?
questions.context: Seeing how interactions produce qualitatively new phenomena not predictable from parts alone.

options.text: Yes - I'm attuned to emergent phenomena and think in terms of emergence
Usually - I recognize emergence when analyzing systems
Sometimes - I notice emergence when it's pointed out
Rarely - I tend to think reductively in terms of components

questions.text: Do you see systems as having properties beyond the sum of their parts?
questions.context: Understanding that interaction effects create new realities.

options.text: Yes - whole-system properties are often what I focus on
Usually - I consider systemic properties for complex systems
Sometimes - I think about system properties when prompted
Rarely - I understand systems through their components

questions.text: Can you predict when scaling will produce qualitative rather than just quantitative changes?
questions.context: Knowing when 'more' becomes 'different' - phase transitions and threshold effects.

options.text: Yes - I anticipate phase transitions and emergence at scale
Usually - I expect nonlinear effects in complex scaling
Sometimes - I notice scaling surprises after they happen
Rarely - I expect smooth scaling unless told otherwise

questions.text: Do you notice when collective behavior can't be explained by individual behavior?
questions.context: Markets, crowds, ecosystems - where group dynamics transcend individual actions.

options.text: Yes - I naturally think at both individual and collective levels
Usually - I consider collective dynamics in social systems
Sometimes - I aggregate individual behavior for predictions
Rarely - I explain collectives through typical individuals

questions.text: Can you identify feedback loops that create self-reinforcing or self-limiting dynamics?
questions.context: Seeing how circular causation produces stable patterns or runaway effects.

options.text: Yes - I naturally see feedback structures and their implications
Usually - I identify feedback loops in systems I analyze
Sometimes - I notice obvious feedback effects
Rarely - I think in linear cause-effect chains

questions.text: Can you fluidly move between levels of abstraction while maintaining coherence?
questions.context: Zooming in and out between concrete details and abstract principles without losing the thread.

options.text: Yes - I seamlessly navigate abstraction levels
Usually - I can move levels with conscious effort
Sometimes - I'm more comfortable at certain levels
Rarely - I prefer to stay at one level of abstraction

questions.text: Can you explain the same thing at multiple levels of detail depending on the audience?
questions.context: Adjusting abstraction level without losing accuracy or coherence.

options.text: Yes - I can present the same idea at any level of abstraction
Usually - I can adjust level for most audiences
Sometimes - I explain better at certain levels
Rarely - I have a natural level I default to

questions.text: When debugging, can you shift between implementation details and architectural overview?
questions.context: Zooming in to code and out to system design while tracking the connection.

options.text: Yes - I move fluidly between detail and overview
Usually - I can shift levels when needed
Sometimes - I'm stronger at one level than the other
Rarely - I work mostly at one level of analysis

questions.text: Can you see how an abstract principle manifests in concrete situations?
questions.context: Instantiating - going from general rule to specific application.

options.text: Yes - I automatically see abstract principles in concrete form
Usually - I can generate concrete examples of abstractions
Sometimes - I need prompting to see concrete manifestations
Rarely - I keep abstractions and concretes somewhat separate

questions.text: Can you extract general principles from specific cases?
questions.context: Abstracting - going from particular instances to general rules.

options.text: Yes - I naturally generalize from examples to principles
Usually - I can identify patterns across cases
Sometimes - I generalize when there are many similar cases
Rarely - I treat cases as individual instances

questions.text: Can you create novel metaphors that generate new understanding?
questions.context: Not just using existing metaphors but inventing new ones that reveal hidden structure.

options.text: Yes - I generate original metaphors that provide new insight
Usually - I can create metaphors when needed
Sometimes - I use and adapt existing metaphors
Rarely - I prefer literal description over metaphor

questions.text: Do metaphors help you discover things, not just communicate them?
questions.context: Using metaphorical mapping to reveal relationships you didn't see before.

options.text: Yes - metaphors are discovery tools for me
Usually - metaphors sometimes lead to insights
Sometimes - metaphors mainly help me explain to others
Rarely - metaphors are primarily communication devices

questions.text: Can you extend a metaphor to generate predictions it wasn't designed for?
questions.context: Taking a metaphorical mapping further to discover unexpected implications.

options.text: Yes - I push metaphors to see what else they predict
Usually - I explore metaphors beyond their obvious application
Sometimes - I use metaphors within their intended scope
Rarely - I don't tend to extend metaphors

questions.text: Do you notice when people are trapped by dead metaphors they don't realize they're using?
questions.context: Seeing how implicit metaphors constrain thinking without awareness.

options.text: Yes - I see metaphorical traps that others don't notice
Usually - I notice when metaphors become problematic
Sometimes - I see obvious metaphorical limitations
Rarely - I don't think much about implicit metaphors

questions.text: Can you find metaphors that bridge domains that seem to have nothing in common?
questions.context: Creating unexpected connections through metaphorical imagination.

options.text: Yes - I find surprising metaphorical bridges regularly
Usually - I can create bridging metaphors with effort
Sometimes - I use metaphors between related domains
Rarely - I keep domains conceptually separate

questions.text: Can you dissolve apparent boundaries between concepts to see underlying unity?
questions.context: Recognizing when distinctions are conventional rather than fundamental.

options.text: Yes - I often see that 'different' concepts are the same thing
Usually - I can see unity when I look for it
Sometimes - I maintain standard conceptual boundaries
Rarely - I work with concepts as distinct entities

questions.text: Do you question whether categorical distinctions are real or conventional?
questions.context: Wondering whether divisions like mind/body, nature/nurture are actually coherent.

options.text: Yes - I routinely question whether categories carve at joints
Usually - I question categories that seem problematic
Sometimes - I accept most categories as given
Rarely - I work within established categories

questions.text: Can you see continuums where others see sharp categories?
questions.context: Recognizing that apparent boundaries are often points on a spectrum.

options.text: Yes - I naturally see gradients rather than categories
Usually - I recognize spectrums when I look for them
Sometimes - I see obvious continuums
Rarely - I think in categories by default

questions.text: Do you notice when experts in different fields are talking about the same phenomenon with different names?
questions.context: Seeing through disciplinary vocabulary to underlying conceptual identity.

options.text: Yes - I frequently identify the same idea wearing different disciplinary costumes
Usually - I recognize cross-disciplinary parallels
Sometimes - I see parallels between related fields
Rarely - I take disciplinary distinctions at face value

questions.text: Can you identify assumptions hidden in the very language used to describe a problem?
questions.context: Seeing how vocabulary presupposes distinctions that may not be valid.

options.text: Yes - I notice how language smuggles in assumptions
Usually - I catch linguistic assumptions when alert
Sometimes - I notice obvious linguistic biases
Rarely - I accept standard descriptions uncritically

questions.text: Can you transform a problem space to make hard problems easy?
questions.context: Finding representations or mappings where difficult problems become trivial.

options.text: Yes - I seek transformations that dissolve problem difficulty
Usually - I can find simplifying transformations with effort
Sometimes - I apply known transformations when they fit
Rarely - I solve problems in their original form

questions.text: Do you look for ways to reformulate problems so solutions become obvious?
questions.context: Changing the problem representation until the answer jumps out.

options.text: Yes - reformulation is often where I find breakthroughs
Usually - I try reformulations when direct approaches fail
Sometimes - I reformulate obvious problem framings
Rarely - I work within the given problem formulation

questions.text: Can you recognize when a problem is hard because of how it's being represented?
questions.context: Seeing that difficulty is sometimes artifactual rather than inherent.

options.text: Yes - I often find that 'hard' problems are poorly represented
Usually - I consider whether representation is the issue
Sometimes - I blame representation when stuck
Rarely - I assume difficulty is inherent to problems

questions.text: Do you solve problems by finding the perspective from which they disappear?
questions.context: Not solving but dissolving - reframing so the problem doesn't arise.

options.text: Yes - dissolution is often more elegant than solution
Usually - I look for dissolving reframes when appropriate
Sometimes - I solve directly but notice when problems dissolve
Rarely - I focus on solving problems as given

questions.text: Can you invert a problem - solving for what you don't want to find what you do?
questions.context: Working backward, solving the dual problem, or negating the objective.

options.text: Yes - inversion is a natural move in my problem-solving
Usually - I try inversion when forward progress stalls
Sometimes - I invert when someone suggests it
Rarely - I approach problems in their natural direction
